title: Non‐immunosuppressive treatment for IgA nephropathy
authors: Tunnicliffe, DJ; Reid, S; Craig, JC; Samuels, JA; Molony, DA; Strippoli, GFM

response.output:
Plain Language Summary Title
What are the benefits and harms of treatments that do not suppress the immune system for IgA nephropathy?

Key Messages
– For people with IgA nephropathy (a type of kidney disease), certain blood pressure medicines called RAS inhibitors probably reduce the amount of protein in the urine. High levels of protein in the urine are a sign of kidney damage. We are less sure if these medicines prevent kidney failure.
– Surgery to remove the tonsils (a tonsillectomy) may help reduce protein and blood in the urine for some people. However, the studies were only done in Japanese people, so we do not know if this treatment would help people of other ethnicities.
– For other treatments that do not suppress the immune system, such as blood thinners, fish oil, or herbal medicines, there is not enough good information to know if they are helpful for IgA nephropathy.

What is IgA nephropathy?
IgA nephropathy is a long-term condition that affects the kidneys. It happens when a protein made by the immune system, called immunoglobulin A (IgA), builds up in the kidneys. This buildup causes damage over time.

The condition develops slowly, but for some people, it can lead to kidney failure over many years. Common signs include blood or protein in the urine, which a doctor can find with tests.

How is IgA nephropathy treated?
Some treatments for IgA nephropathy work by weakening the body's immune system to stop it from attacking the kidneys. However, these treatments can have serious side effects.

This review looked at treatments that do not suppress the immune system. These include:
– medicines to lower blood pressure
– surgery to remove the tonsils
– blood thinners (medicines that help prevent blood clots)
– fish oil supplements
– traditional Chinese medicines

What did we want to find out?
We wanted to find out the benefits and harms of these treatments for adults and children with IgA nephropathy.

We were especially interested in how these treatments affected:
– kidney failure
– the amount of protein in the urine
– the amount of blood in the urine
– any unwanted or harmful effects

What did we do?
We searched for studies that compared these treatments with a fake treatment (a placebo), no treatment, or standard care.

We compared and summarized the results of the studies. We also rated our confidence in the evidence, based on factors such as how the studies were done and how many people were in them.

What did we find?
We found 80 studies that included 4856 people with IgA nephropathy.

Blood pressure medicines
Medicines called RAS inhibitors were the most studied treatment. Compared to a fake treatment or no treatment, RAS inhibitors probably reduce the amount of protein in the urine. We are not sure if they prevent kidney failure because the studies did not look at this for long enough. These medicines may not cause any more unwanted effects than a fake treatment.

Removing the tonsils (tonsillectomy)
Surgery to remove the tonsils may help some people get rid of protein and blood in their urine. It may also reduce the chance of these problems coming back. However, these studies were only done in Japan. This means we do not know if the results would be the same for people from other parts of the world.

Other treatments
For other treatments like blood thinners, fish oil, and traditional Chinese medicines, we did not find enough evidence to be sure if they help improve kidney health compared to standard care.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
Our confidence in the results is limited for several reasons. Many of the studies we found were small and did not last long enough to measure important long-term effects like kidney failure.

There were also problems with how some of the studies were carried out. Because of these issues, we cannot be certain about many of the findings. More and better research is needed to understand the best way to treat IgA nephropathy.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to December 2023.
